Author: greendestiny
Content:
Print yourself an emacs cheatsheet, key combinations get a little cryptic but they are the fastest way to interact with an editor (I think its probably good to use them even in other editors)

This sheet's a little basic, but its a start:\nhttp://ccrma.stanford.edu/guides/package/emacs/emacs.html

Author: Zak
Content: I think Aaron's evil plot was to use machine learning to provide an automated friend-of-a-friend introduction service based on what you wrote on your infogami page. I'm pretty sure he posted about it somewhere - I remember because I had the same idea. Maybe this is a new platform for that idea.

Author: dfranke
Content: Depends what I'm hacking.  I actually use both vi and emacs -- vi for quick edits and emacs for more serious work.  Eclipse for Java but nothing else.  I'll resort to ed if I'm on a system where I don't have my emacs customizations and vi isn't vim.

Author: cstejerean
Content: Probably true, but it tastes a lot better than redbull.

Author: cstejerean
Title: Yahoo Mash: The Social Network for Graffiti Lovers

Author: bp
Content:
Vi. The simplicity, speed, and the fact that it is installed on any *nix system by default are my favorite aspects of Vi. I've played around with Vim, but haven't migrated to it because I just don't use the features.

At times, I have been tempted to move to Emacs due to all its cool features but have not yet, maybe some day. Emacs in slime mode has been great to use while learning lisp.

Author: Zak
Content: I learned it for Slime, and started using it for everything else when every other editor felt crippled.
